citations.narrative:
The facility has an indoor public interaction with their ring-tailed lemurs several times each day. Small groups enter the
lemur enclosure, housing 10 lemurs of varying ages, with an attendant and are allowed to stand or sit in the enclosure
with a small amount of food provided by the facility. The lemurs are allowed to approach the public at their discretion
without any direct control. During one interaction, an adult woman and a child were sitting on a bench when a lemur
jumped on the woman’s shoulder and then another lemur jumped on the child’s head from behind. During another
interaction, an adult woman and two children entered the enclosure and multiple lemurs jumped on their shoulders as
soon as they entered the enclosure. Because of the number of lemurs, the attendant was ineffective in trying to control
the lemur activity. Direct contact, especially of the face, head, and shoulder area, by a lemur that is not under the direct
control of the attendant may result in scratches or bites. Trained nonhuman primates may be permitted physical contact
with the public only if they are under the direct control and supervision of an experienced handler at all times during the
contact. The licensee must ensure that during public exhibition, animals are handled so that there is minimal risk of harm
to the animal and to the public.
To be corrected by: 8.1.24

At the time of the inspection, a lemur chased a single Lapwing bird that was housed in the same enclosure, cornered it,
and held on to it with both hands until it was reprimanded by the Manager . The bird was not physically injured by the
lemur. Birds are not to be housed with other animals, including members of their own species, unless they are compatible.
Compatibility must be determined in accordance with generally accepted professional practices and by actual
observations to ensure that the animals are compatible. To ensure the safety and well-being of the Lapwing, the licensee
shall separate the animals and ensure that the bird is housed in a safe environment.
To be corrected by: 7.26.24
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with Facility Representative.
Additional Inspectors:
KONSTANZE PLUMLEE, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
2.131(c)(1) 
   
Handling of animals. 
The facility has an indoor public interaction with their ring-tailed lemurs several times each day. Small groups enter the 
lemur enclosure, housing 10 lemurs of varying ages, with an attendant and are allowed to stand or sit in the enclosure 
with a small amount of food provided by the facility. The lemurs are allowed to approach the public at their discretion 
without any direct control. During one interaction, an adult woman and a child were sitting on a bench when a lemur 
jumped on the woman’s shoulder and then another lemur jumped on the child’s head from behind. During another 
interaction, an adult woman and two children entered the enclosure and multiple lemurs jumped on their shoulders as 
soon as they entered the enclosure. Because of the number of lemurs, the attendant was ineffective in trying to control 
the lemur activity. Direct contact, especially of the face, head, and shoulder area, by a lemur that is not under the direct 
control of the attendant may result in scratches or bites. Trained nonhuman primates may be permitted physical contact 
with the public only if they are under the direct control and supervision of an experienced handler at all times during the 
contact. The licensee must ensure that during public exhibition, animals are handled so that there is minimal risk of harm 
to the animal and to the public. 
To be corrected by: 8.1.24 
3.160(b) 
   
Compatibility and separation 
At the time of the inspection, a lemur chased a single Lapwing bird that was housed in the same enclosure, cornered it, 
and held on to it with both hands until it was reprimanded by the Manager . The bird was not physically injured by the 
lemur. Birds are not to be housed with other animals, including members of their own species, unless they are compatible. 
Compatibility must be determined in accordance with generally accepted professional practices and by actual 
observations to ensure that the animals are compatible. To ensure the safety and well-being of the Lapwing, the licensee 
shall separate the animals and ensure that the bird is housed in a safe environment. 
To be corrected by: 7.26.24 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with Facility Representative.

Additional Inspectors: 
KONSTANZE PLUMLEE, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
